aspect.name: Genomics
aspect.subtitle: Genome annotation
aspect.intro-text: The gene structure and other genome annotation in FlyMine are provided by a variety of curated source databases. In most cases FlyMine includes all genome features that have chromosomal locations (eg. genes and repeat regions).
aspect.starting-points: Gene Transcript Exon TRNA NcRNA Chromosome ChromosomeBand Orthologue Paralogue IntergenicRegion GOTerm RepeatRegion TransposableElement TFBindingSite Pseudogene RRNA SnRNA SnoRNA UTR MRNA

aspect.name: Gene Expression
aspect.subtitle: ArrayExpress
aspect.intro-text: FlyMine contains selected Microarray gene expression data sets for Drosophila melanogaster. We plan to add more soon.

aspect.name: Transcriptional Regulation
aspect.subtitle:
Regulatory regions and
transcription factor binding sites
aspect.intro-text: Regulatory regions from REDfly and transcription factor binding sites from FlyReg and FlyBase.

aspect.name: DrosDel
aspect.subtitle:
P-element insertions
and deletions
aspect.intro-text: DrosDel P-element insertion and deletion locations.

aspect.name: Tiling Path
aspect.subtitle: Microarray Tiling Primers
aspect.intro-text: Primers designed to tile across whole genomes or regions of genomes.

aspect.name: INDAC
aspect.subtitle:
Long oligos from the
International Drosophila Array Consortium
aspect.intro-text: Long oligos from the International Drosophila Array Consortium.

aspect.name: RNAi
aspect.subtitle: RNA interference
aspect.intro-text: FlyMine currently contains RNAi experiment results only for Caenorhabditis elegans. By using orthologues, gene phenotypes in other organisms can be inferred from the C. elegans RNAi experiments.

aspect.name: Comparative Genomics
aspect.subtitle: Orthologues and paralogues
aspect.intro-text: Orthologues and Paralogues. Orthologues are equivalent genes in different species that evolved from a common ancestor by speciation. Paralogues are genes from the same homologous superfamily found in another part of the genome of a particular taxon. Paralogues are the result of gene duplication.

aspect.name: Proteins
aspect.subtitle:
Protein and
proteomics data
aspect.intro-text: Protein annotation (including family and domain annotation) from UniProt and InterPro.

aspect.name: Protein Interactions
aspect.subtitle: IntAct
aspect.intro-text: Proteins formatted in the Proteomics Standards Initiative (PSI) molecular interaction (PSI MI) format can be mapped to the FlyMine data model.

aspect.name: Protein Structure
aspect.subtitle: 3-D protein structures
aspect.intro-text: 3-D protein structures from the Mizuguchi lab.
aspect.starting-points: Protein ProteinStructure ProteinRegion ProteinFeature ProteinDomain ProteinFamily

aspect.name: Gene Ontology
aspect.intro-text:
The Gene Ontology (GO) project is a collaborative effort to address the need for consistent descriptions of gene products in different databases.

The GO collaborators are developing three structured, controlled vocabularies (ontologies) that describe gene products in terms of their associated biological processes, cellular components and molecular functions in a species-independent manner.

GO annotations for Drosophila, C. elegans and A. gambiae have been loaded into FlyMine. The GO annotations are 'attached' to Genes and so each gene has a reference (link) to a list of its GO annotations (if available).
